<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you’re reading this while waiting in line to vote, here are some ideas to help pass the time (after you’ve read this newsletter, of course):</p>

<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Markets: </strong></span><span>Three days before Halloween, they’re officially spooked. U.S. stocks followed their European pals </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/27/stock-market-futures-open-to-close-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">down the gutter</a></span><span> yesterday, and the S&P had its worst one-day drop since June.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Economy: </strong></span><span>Big day today. The Commerce Department will release data on </span><span><a href="https://www.npr.org/2020/10/28/928258913/glass-half-full-record-u-s-gdp-growth-will-mask-a-deeply-hurting-economy?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">third-quarter GDP</a></span><span> (our broadest measure of economic activity). The numbers will probably show the strongest quarterly growth on record in the U.S. However, Q3 also followed the biggest GDP </span><span><em>drop</em></span><span> on record, so the numbers won’t reflect a rip-roaring economy.</span>
</li>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PUBLIC HEALTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/28/europe-locked-downagain?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Europe Locks Down, Part Deux
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A lock draped with the French and German flags " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTUxL2V1cm9wZV9sb2NrZG93bi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facing alarming numbers of Covid-19 infections, hospitalizations, and deaths, Germany and France <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus/germany-and-france-prepare-new-lockdowns-as-covid-sweeps-europe-idUSKBN27D1J2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tightened</a> restrictions on businesses and social life yesterday with the most dramatic measures they have taken since the spring. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The WHO said the European region accounted for almost half of the new Covid-19 cases reported last week. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The epicenter of Europe’s second wave is the epicenter of its wine culture: France. The country’s seven-day average of new daily cases <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/france-emerges-as-covid-19-epicenter-as-cases-surge-across-europe-11603817793?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jumped</a> over 50% in the past week, and its hospitals are at risk of being overwhelmed. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>There was already a curfew from 9pm to 6am in France’s larger cities. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Then yesterday, President Emmanuel Macron announced a nationwide lockdown nearly as strict as those imposed in March; people are allowed to leave their homes only for school, essential goods, and work—if their employer says it’s impossible to do the job from home. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">France’s neighbor Germany <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/germany-to-shut-restaurants-bars-to-combat-coronavirus-spread-11603904742?mod=breakingnews&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">also enacted</a> a partial, month-long lockdown. German restaurants, bars, gyms, concert halls, and theaters will close starting Nov. 2.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The government will spend up to 10 billion euros (about $11.8 billion) to cover some lost sales for affected businesses. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Some economists say governments should pursue measured lockdown orders to prevent kneecapping the global economy like we saw in the spring. But others say a brief, strict lockdown is the best approach to getting infections under control so businesses can open back up sooner. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The moves made the Continent’s stock markets swoon </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Stoxx 600, a pan-European index, <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/28/european-m.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suffered</a> its worst one-day drop since September ahead of Macron’s announcement. France’s CAC and Germany’s DAX dipped 3.7% and more than 4.4%, respectively. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The U.S. and Europe have resoundingly failed to hold onto the progress made over the summer against the virus. Many East Asian countries resoundingly haven’t; South Korean President Moon Jae-in <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-28/south-korea-s-moon-says-virus-contained-seeks-to-revive-economy?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said on Tuesday</a> his country has contained the coronavirus. </p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/28/google-facebook-twitter-ceos-spar-us-lawmakers-section-230?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Once Again, Tech Butts Are in the Hot Seat
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Big Tech’s version of the Avengers assembled yesterday, when Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, and Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai <a href="https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-media-social-media-1246ed1fe238971bb2509e0a8f76b0a6?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">faced off</a> against a Senate panel over the widespread protections Section 230 offers their tech empires.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Quick refresher: </strong></span><span>Section 230 is a 26-word provision tucked away in a 1996 law that says internet companies cannot be held liable for the content their users post. It’s been attacked by both conservatives and liberals, and even the CEOs themselves for its imprecise language and sweeping consequences. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here are the best soundbites from the feisty affair:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">"Section 230 is the Internet’s most important law for free speech and safety.” </strong>Jack Dorsey claimed that <a href="https://www.foxnews.com/politics/doj-citing-hunter-biden-story-justice-thomas-supports-changes-to-section-230-in-letter-to-congress?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">weakening</a> the protections offered by the law would change the fabric of the digital world. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“Congress should update the law to make sure it’s working as intended.” </strong>Zuckerberg said he supports change because more clarity around content moderation benefits everybody, including the platforms. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">"Mr. Dorsey, who the hell elected you and put you in charge of what the media are allowed to report…?</strong>” Republican Senator Ted Cruz broke out the H-E-double-hockey-sticks, <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/facebook-twitter-google-ceos-to-defend-section-230-before-senate-panel/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reprimanding Twitter</a> for disabling the sharing of a NY Post article about Hunter Biden. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“The issue is not that these companies...are taking too many posts down. The issue is that they are leaving too many dangerous posts up.</strong>” Democratic Senator Ed Markey said tech companies could <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/senate-tech-hearing-facebook-twitter-google-11603849274?mod=business_lead_pos7&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">go further</a> in limiting the spread of hate speech and misinformation. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ELECTION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/28/trumps-promises-wisconsin-manufacturing-workers-disappoint?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Did Wisconsin Voters Get Foxconned?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="President Donald Trump participates in a groundbreaking for a Foxconn facility at the Wisconsin Valley Science and Technology Park June 28, 2018" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTUzL2ZveGNvbm4uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Brendan Smialowski/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>This article is part of our weeklong series exploring state-level issues in the upcoming election. </em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In 2018, President Trump visited Wisconsin to break ground on what he called “the eighth wonder of the world,” a high-tech manufacturing facility for TV screens that would bring 13,000 jobs and $10 billion in investment to the swing state. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Narrator: It didn’t go as planned </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Behind the project is Taiwan’s <a href="https://www.theverge.com/21507966/foxconn-empty-factories-wisconsin-jobs-loophole-trump?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Foxconn Technology Group</a>, famous for its role as Apple’s main manufacturing partner. But more than two years later, the grand vision has been <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/politics/elections/2020/10/27/foxconn-construction-continues-but-company-silent-hiring/3733727001/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">downgraded</a>—the facility is now set to produce less-advanced screens—and Wisconsin officials aren’t sure what they’re getting.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Foxconn was set to receive as much as $4 billion in incentives if it met certain targets. But the company has fallen short in hiring and investments. In 2019, it brought on less than a quarter of the planned 2,000+ employees.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>For the second year running, Foxconn was denied incentives under the agreement. It’s renegotiating the terms with Wisconsin officials as construction continues. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Trump was personally involved in the deal from the beginning, and for his critics, this factory is a high-profile example of campaign promises to manufacturing workers, especially in the Rust Belt, that <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/16/trump-manufacturing-jobs-record-415588?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">haven't been fulfilled</a>. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

AVIATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/28/heathrow-no-longer-europes-busiest-airport?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Quick—Name Europe’s Busiest Airport
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you said London’s Heathrow, you’d have been correct...until yesterday. Heathrow said it had been <a href="https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-europe-london-65ddad039c72425985a5b2487490cef2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">overtaken</a> by Charles de Gaulle in Paris as the busiest airport in Europe, with Amsterdam Schiphol and Frankfurt “close behind.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What happened? </strong>We could say “the coronavirus,” but Paris, Amsterdam, and Frankfurt had to deal with that, too. Specifically, Heathrow’s bosses blamed the British government for being <a href="https://thehill.com/policy/international/europe/523107-paris-airport-overtakes-londons-heathrow-as-busiest-in-europe?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">too slow</a> to implement a Covid-19 testing program at the airport, while its rivals <em>had</em> installed testing systems. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Passenger testing is important because it allows travelers to avoid long quarantines following a trip. You can imagine more people might travel through Heathrow if they knew they could avoid quarantine.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>No matter what airport you fly out of, you won’t have to wrestle anyone for the charging outlet. Heathrow’s passenger numbers fell 69% in the first nine months of the year; Charles De Gaulle traffic fell 67%. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>to recapture the European throne, Heathrow’s CEO said Britain needs to install pre-departure Covid tests and partner with the U.S. to open a “pilot airbridge to America.”</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/28/founder-utahbased-tech-company-qualtrics-buys-utah-jazz?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
This Guy Just Bought the Utah Jazz
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Ryan Smith speaking in a Qualtrics hat" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTU0L3J5YW5fc21pdGguanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Clodagh Kilcoyne/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Ryan Smith, the billionaire founder of Qualtrics, acquired a majority stake in another Utah-based business yesterday for a reported $1.6 billion: the Utah Jazz. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Ryan Smith: boring name, interesting dude</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While most kids get their dad’s eye color or temperament, Smith used a survey tool his <a href="https://www.deseret.com/sports/2020/10/28/21538508/ryan-smith-utah-jazz-qualtrics-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-utah-jazz-new-owner?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">father developed</a> for academics to start Qualtrics in Provo, UT, in 2002. He took the idea and turned it into a software behemoth that over 11,000 organizations in 100 countries now use to measure customer experience.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In 2018, just before Smith was set to take Qualtrics public at a $5 billion valuation, European software giant SAP </span><span><a href="https://www.deseret.com/2018/11/11/20658607/utah-s-qualtrics-acquired-by-german-tech-giant-in-monumental-8-billion-deal#qualtrics-ceo-ryan-smith-left-plays-basketball-with-employees-at-the-business-in-provo-on-feb-2-2018-qualtrics-is-a-global-leader-in-the-realm-of-customer-experience-analytics-and-was-acquired-sunday-for-8-billion?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">offered $8 billion</a></span><span> to buy the company, which Smith accepted.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The Jazz are jazzed to have him: </strong>For the past three years, Smith has collaborated with the team on a first-of-its-kind <a href="https://www.nba.com/jazz/news/gail-miller-and-family-announce-agreement-sell-majority-interest-utah-jazz-qualtrics-founder-0?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">philanthropic jersey patch</a> that’s raised $25 million. And he loves Utah even more than your friend who just came back from Zion—Qualtrics is currently doubling the size of its Provo HQ. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Smith joins an NBA owners club with more tech billionaires than a U.S. Senate hearing: Mark Cuban, ex-Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer, Alibaba cofounder Joseph Tsai, and former AOL exec Ted Leonsis all own teams. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
How to Fact Check Social Media
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Homer Simpson on the Internet" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=503 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/3orieNLnAxzZI9CQzm/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Homer Simpson on the Internet" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/3orieNLnAxzZI9CQzm/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Despite rising concerns about the spread of fake news, almost one in five U.S. adults mostly use social media to stay current.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But tech execs like Zuck and Dorsey are still new to the whole “controlling the global dissemination of news” thing. So, just like you wouldn’t trust someone who recently got their learner’s permit to drive your Jeep, you shouldn’t trust social media to filter your perfect cup of fresh-brewed, fact-checked news. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As we barrel roll toward the election, the news you read on social media won’t just affect <em>your</em> vote, but liking or sharing it could send posts spiraling into the East Australian Current that is going viral. And if the post is anything less than factual, that would be like, totally not cool, dude. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To help, the Brew’s social media expert Jamie Wilde created a step-by-step guide that walks you through how to suss out fact from fiction when looking at a social media post. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 1.38;"><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/28/5-12-steps-fact-checking-social-media-feed?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Dive in here</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The electoral college has received a lot of criticism, but since it’s still around...we might as well quiz you about it. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How this game works:</strong> We’ll give you two states; you have to choose the state with more presidential electors. </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Texas or New York</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Georgia or Colorado</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Maine or Vermont</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Ohio or Wisconsin</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>New Jersey or Virginia</span></li>

style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMarkets: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThree days before Halloween, they’re officially spooked. U.S. stocks followed their European pals \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/27/stock-market-futures-open-to-close-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edown the gutter\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e yesterday, and the S\u0026P had its worst one-day drop since June.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eEconomy: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBig day today. The Commerce Department will release data on \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2020/10/28/928258913/glass-half-full-record-u-s-gdp-growth-will-mask-a-deeply-hurting-economy?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethird-quarter GDP\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e (our broadest measure of economic activity). The numbers will probably show the strongest quarterly growth on record in the U.S. However, Q3 also followed the biggest GDP \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003edrop\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e on record, so the numbers won’t reflect a rip-roaring economy.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nPUBLIC HEALTH \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nEurope Locks Down, Part Deux\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A lock draped with the French and German flags \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTUxL2V1cm9wZV9sb2NrZG93bi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFacing alarming numbers of Covid-19 infections, hospitalizations, and deaths, Germany and France \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus/germany-and-france-prepare-new-lockdowns-as-covid-sweeps-europe-idUSKBN27D1J2?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etightened\u003c/a\u003e restrictions on businesses and social life yesterday with the most dramatic measures they have taken since the spring. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe WHO said the European region accounted for almost half of the new Covid-19 cases reported last week. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe epicenter of Europe’s second wave is the epicenter of its wine culture: France. The country’s seven-day average of new daily cases \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/france-emerges-as-covid-19-epicenter-as-cases-surge-across-europe-11603817793?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejumped\u003c/a\u003e over 50% in the past week, and its hospitals are at risk of being overwhelmed. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThere was already a curfew from 9pm to 6am in France’s larger cities. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThen yesterday, President Emmanuel Macron announced a nationwide lockdown nearly as strict as those imposed in March; people are allowed to leave their homes only for school, essential goods, and work—if their employer says it’s impossible to do the job from home. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFrance’s neighbor Germany \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/germany-to-shut-restaurants-bars-to-combat-coronavirus-spread-11603904742?mod=breakingnews\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ealso enacted\u003c/a\u003e a partial, month-long lockdown. German restaurants, bars, gyms, concert halls, and theaters will close starting Nov. 2.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe government will spend up to 10 billion euros (about $11.8 billion) to cover some lost sales for affected businesses. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eSome economists say governments should pursue measured lockdown orders to prevent kneecapping the global economy like we saw in the spring. But others say a brief, strict lockdown is the best approach to getting infections under control so businesses can open back up sooner. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe moves made the Continent’s stock markets swoon \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Stoxx 600, a pan-European index, \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/28/european-m.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuffered\u003c/a\u003e its worst one-day drop since September ahead of Macron’s announcement. France’s CAC and Germany’s DAX dipped 3.7% and more than 4.4%, respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe U.S. and Europe have resoundingly failed to hold onto the progress made over the summer against the virus. Many East Asian countries resoundingly haven’t; South Korean President Moon Jae-in \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-28/south-korea-s-moon-says-virus-contained-seeks-to-revive-economy?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid on Tuesday\u003c/a\u003e his country has contained the coronavirus. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- 230 offers their tech empires.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eQuick refresher: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSection 230 is a 26-word provision tucked away in a 1996 law that says internet companies cannot be held liable for the content their users post. It’s been attacked by both conservatives and liberals, and even the CEOs themselves for its imprecise language and sweeping consequences. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHere are the best soundbites from the feisty affair:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\"Section 230 is the Internet’s most important law for free speech and safety.” \u003c/strong\u003eJack Dorsey claimed that \u003ca href=\"https://www.foxnews.com/politics/doj-citing-hunter-biden-story-justice-thomas-supports-changes-to-section-230-in-letter-to-congress?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eweakening\u003c/a\u003e the protections offered by the law would change the fabric of the digital world. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e“Congress should update the law to make sure it’s working as intended.” \u003c/strong\u003eZuckerberg said he supports change because more clarity around content moderation benefits everybody, including the platforms. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\"Mr. Dorsey, who the hell elected you and put you in charge of what the media are allowed to report…?\u003c/strong\u003e” Republican Senator Ted Cruz broke out the H-E-double-hockey-sticks, \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnet.com/news/facebook-twitter-google-ceos-to-defend-section-230-before-senate-panel/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereprimanding Twitter\u003c/a\u003e for disabling the sharing of a NY Post article about Hunter Biden. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e“The issue is not that these companies...are taking too many posts down. The issue is that they are leaving too many dangerous posts up.\u003c/strong\u003e” Democratic Senator Ed Markey said tech companies could \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/senate-tech-hearing-facebook-twitter-google-11603849274?mod=business_lead_pos7\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ego further\u003c/a\u003e in limiting the spread of hate speech and misinformation. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS Foxconned?\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"President Donald Trump participates in a groundbreaking for a style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eBrendan Smialowski/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis article is part of our weeklong series exploring state-level issues in the upcoming election. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn 2018, President Trump visited Wisconsin to break ground on what he called “the eighth wonder of the world,” a high-tech manufacturing facility for TV screens that would bring 13,000 jobs and $10 billion in investment to the swing state. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eNarrator: It didn’t go as planned \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBehind the project is Taiwan’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/21507966/foxconn-empty-factories-wisconsin-jobs-loophole-trump?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFoxconn Technology Group\u003c/a\u003e, famous for its role as Apple’s main manufacturing partner. But more than two years later, the grand vision has been \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/politics/elections/2020/10/27/foxconn-construction-continues-but-company-silent-hiring/3733727001/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edowngraded\u003c/a\u003e—the facility is now set to produce less-advanced screens—and Wisconsin officials aren’t sure what they’re getting.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFoxconn was set to receive as much as $4 billion in incentives if it met certain targets. But the company has fallen short in hiring and investments. In 2019, it brought on less than a quarter of the planned 2,000+ employees.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFor the second year running, Foxconn was denied incentives under the agreement. It’s renegotiating the terms with Wisconsin officials as construction continues. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e Trump was personally involved in the deal from the beginning, and for his critics, this factory is a high-profile example of campaign promises to manufacturing workers, especially in the Rust Belt, that \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/16/trump-manufacturing-jobs-record-415588?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehaven't been fulfilled\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" Airport\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you said London’s Heathrow, you’d have been correct...until yesterday. Heathrow said it had been \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-europe-london-65ddad039c72425985a5b2487490cef2?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eovertaken\u003c/a\u003e by Charles de Gaulle in Paris as the busiest airport in Europe, with Amsterdam Schiphol and Frankfurt “close behind.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat happened? \u003c/strong\u003eWe could say “the coronavirus,” but Paris, Amsterdam, and Frankfurt had to deal with that, too. Specifically, Heathrow’s bosses blamed the British government for being \u003ca href=\"https://thehill.com/policy/international/europe/523107-paris-airport-overtakes-londons-heathrow-as-busiest-in-europe?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etoo slow\u003c/a\u003e to implement a Covid-19 testing program at the airport, while its rivals \u003cem\u003ehad\u003c/em\u003e installed testing systems. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePassenger testing is important because it allows travelers to avoid long quarantines following a trip. You can imagine more people might travel through Heathrow if they knew they could avoid quarantine.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eNo matter what airport you fly out of, you won’t have to wrestle anyone for the charging outlet. Heathrow’s passenger numbers fell 69% in the first nine months of the year; Charles De Gaulle traffic fell 67%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eto recapture the European throne, Heathrow’s CEO said Britain needs to install pre-departure Covid tests and partner with the U.S. to open a “pilot airbridge to America.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRyan Smith, the billionaire founder of Qualtrics, href=\"https://www.deseret.com/sports/2020/10/28/21538508/ryan-smith-utah-jazz-qualtrics-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-utah-jazz-new-owner?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efather developed\u003c/a\u003e for academics to start Qualtrics in Provo, UT, in 2002. He took the idea and turned it into a software behemoth that over 11,000 organizations in 100 countries now use to measure customer experience.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIn 2018, just before Smith was set to take Qualtrics public at a $5 billion valuation, European software giant SAP \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.deseret.com/2018/11/11/20658607/utah-s-qualtrics-acquired-by-german-tech-giant-in-monumental-8-billion-deal#qualtrics-ceo-ryan-smith-left-plays-basketball-with-employees-at-the-business-in-provo-on-feb-2-2018-qualtrics-is-a-global-leader-in-the-realm-of-customer-experience-analytics-and-was-acquired-sunday-for-8-billion?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eoffered $8 billion\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to buy the company, which Smith accepted.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe Jazz are jazzed to have him: \u003c/strong\u003eFor the past three years, Smith has collaborated with the team on a first-of-its-kind \u003ca href=\"https://www.nba.com/jazz/news/gail-miller-and-family-announce-agreement-sell-majority-interest-utah-jazz-qualtrics-founder-0?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ephilanthropic jersey patch\u003c/a\u003e that’s raised $25 million. And he loves Utah even more than your friend who just came back from Zion—Qualtrics is currently doubling the size of its Provo HQ. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eSmith joins an NBA owners club with more tech billionaires than a
